topics.Architecture: Microservices, DDD, containere (Docker, Rocket...), event-sourcing, asynchronous services, fault tolerant systems, REST, dependency injection, web services without frameworks, web services without app servers, in-memory computing
topics.Mobile: Mobile first design, testing tools, multi-platform development, Apple Watch, iOS, Android, Windows Mobile
topics.Devops: Infrastructure as code, provisioning, continuous deployment
topics.Persistence: NoSQL, SQL, big data, cloud, grid
topics.Test code: Writing good tests, testing tools, continuous testing, TDD, BDD
topics.Programming: Paradigms, parallelism, typing, languages (C#, F#, Scala, Elixir, Clojure, etc.)
topics.Tools: Version control, build systems, SaaS, analysis (Sonar, R, etc.)
topics.Platforms and other: Cloud, Internet of Things, CMS, CRM, Office 365, EPiServer

collections.details: Johan Strid, Business Area Manager, Knowit Solutions, with a short talk about Knowit, trends, openness and other things.

health_care_servicebus.speaker: Don Janssen
health_care_servicebus.title: Building a healthcare service bus
health_care_servicebus.description: In a hospital lots of different systems are used and usually they do not work very well together. At the same time systems need to share information with each other and patients and authorities want information regardless of the system that stores the information. To solve this problem we are building a service bus for the county of Västerbotten, based on principles for domain driven architecture, SOA, REST and MicroServices, using .Net and Web API. The service bus handles routing, service discovery and has an engagement index that keeps track of patients and in which system they have data. Although every service is independent of the other a lot of functionality is the same for every service, therefore we created a framework existing of NuGet packages. As part of the project we also build a web portal on top of the service bus that makes the information about the patients accessible for the hospital's employees. In this talk I will discuss the challenges but most important the solutions we are working on to solve those integrations.

f#_whats_in_it_4_me.speaker: Toni Kaihola
f#_whats_in_it_4_me.title: F# : what's in it for me?
f#_whats_in_it_4_me.description: Join me on a whirlwind tour into the functional cousin of C#. We will cover many areas of the language, including the powerful type system and useful language constructs. You will get answers to the following questions: How can you code without nulls? What if you could do calculations with units of measurements such as m/s ? Using extension methods without extension methods, how? How can you get value equality for free? I have a lot of existing C# or VB code. Can I somehow benefit from F#? Finally we will explore tools that you can use to get acquainted with F# scripting and tools which you can use with your existing .NET projects and beyond.

git_enemy_friend.speaker: Christoffer Eliesen
git_enemy_friend.title: Git - From your worst enemy to your best friend
git_enemy_friend.description: In this talk I'll present my workflow when using git, including some advanced features, in order to showcase how you can get the most out of using this powerful tool.

managing_containers_kubernetes.speaker: Ole Bakstad
managing_containers_kubernetes.title: Managing your containers with Kubernetes
managing_containers_kubernetes.description: During the last few years containers have become a common word in the tech vocabulary. There are many providers that offer solutions for managing containers for example Google Cloud Platform, Amazon AWS and Mesosphere. This talk will introduce Kubernetes from Google, a orchestration tool that offer automated deployment, scaling and management of your containers. You will learn the core concepts and features of Kubernetes and gain insight in how it differs from similar solutions like Amazon Container Service or Mesosphere. I will also give a live demo of these features. The demo will show how to easily load balance between multiple container instances, auto scale your application and how to do canary releases and rolling upgrades with zero down time.

emerging_architectures.speaker: Jan Stenberg
emerging_architectures.title: Emerging Architectures
emerging_architectures.description: I will talk about architectures, that may be old, but gets an increasing interest today, because of their simplicity and how well they fit in the services and cloud world of today.

mlaas_machine_learning.speaker: Anders Breivik
mlaas_machine_learning.title: MLaaS - Machine Learning for the rest of us
mlaas_machine_learning.description: What is Machine Learning as a Service? Which do I choose? How can I use it in my application? Machine learning has long been a somewhat academic discipline, its practitioners highly specialized. But with the advent of a new class of commoditized machine learning platforms, MLaaS, Machine Learning as a Service, is now available to all developers. MLaaS can be treated as a black box, giving developers the opportunity to dive into machine learning head first. Supply your own data, build a model using tools supported by your chosen MLaaS platform and train it using the well tested algorithms offered. When ready to dig deeper into the world of machine learning, most MLaaS platforms enables us to develop our own algorithms even better tailored to our data and models. This talk will show you the state of the art of MLaaS, what the different vendors offers, and where you best can put it to use in your applications.

drones_with_js.speaker: Anders Breivik
drones_with_js.title: Programming mini drones with JavaScript
drones_with_js.description: In this talk you will learn how to program popular over-the-counter flying mini drones with JavaScript for fun and profit. Well, mostly for fun, but while having fun you can learn JavaScript, node.js, physical computing, Internet of Things and other stuff that surely can be profitable. Cylon.js is a node.js based JavaScript framework for robtics and physical computing. It supports an extensive range of hardware, from remote controlled toys to IoT devices. Cylon.js is great for abstracting away the annoying aspects of hardware coding, leaving the fun part: seeing your code bridge the gap from the digital to the physical world. There might be live coding, and if the demo gods favour us, a live drone show!
